question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable for demonstration whenever possible. Please help me implement this SVG image using code. The ear is the human organ for hearing and the sense of listening to sound and noise.

checklist.title: Is the basic SVG ear anatomy correctly implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements the primary anatomical features of the human ear (outer ear, middle ear, inner ear) through SVG paths and elements. Score 0 if only a simplified outline is created, 5 if the main visible structures are implemented, and 10 if all anatomical structures (including internal components like cochlea, auditory canal, etc.) are accurately represented with proper proportions.

checklist.title: Are the SVG paths anatomically accurate and detailed?
checklist.description: Examine the path definitions for anatomical accuracy. Check whether bezier curves and line segments properly follow the natural curvature of ear structures. Verify that the helix, antihelix, tragus, lobule, and other ear components are accurately represented. Deduct 3 points for each significant anatomical inaccuracy, and 5 points if the proportions between different ear parts are incorrect. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the SVG rendering optimized with appropriate attributes?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code uses appropriate SVG attributes for element optimization (viewBox, preserveAspectRatio, etc.) and whether the coordinate system is properly defined. Check for proper use of groups (<g>), reusable components (symbols, defs), and efficient path commands. Deduct 3 points for inefficient SVG structure, 5 points for missing viewBox definition, and 3 points for unnecessarily verbose path commands. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the implementation include educational or interactive elements related to hearing function?
checklist.description: Assess whether the code implements educational features that explain the hearing process or ear functionality. Check for hover explanations, animated sound wave visualization, or labeled anatomical parts. Score 0 if the image is purely static with no educational elements, 5 if basic labels or tooltips are included, and 10 if comprehensive interactive educational features explain the hearing process.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle different display environments (browser compatibility, responsiveness), includes fallback options, and provides appropriate error handling for animations or interactions. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle edge cases like resizing, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no safeguards are implemented, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Sound wave visualization when interacting with the ear 2. Cross-sectional view transitions 3. Animated explanation of how sound travels through the ear). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant SVG elements or groups that could be consolidated 2. Unnecessary animations or effects unrelated to ear function demonstration 3. Excessive detail that impacts performance without adding educational value. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core anatomical representation is obscured by redundant elements.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating structure/style/interaction concerns), code reusability, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if inline styles are overused instead of CSS classes; deduct 5 points if the code contains duplicated path definitions that could be reused; deduct 5 points if there's no clear organization of SVG components. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the visual representation meet professional anatomical illustration standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows professional medical illustration principles: 1) Appropriate color scheme for anatomical clarity 2) Proper use of shading and gradients to indicate depth 3) Clear visual distinction between different ear structures. Deduct 3 points for each anatomical misrepresentation, 5 points for confusing or unrealistic coloring, and 5 points for poor visual hierarchy that makes structures difficult to distinguish. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and educational?
checklist.description: Judge whether any interactive elements enhance understanding of ear function: 1) Transitions between different ear views are smooth (300-500ms) 2) Hover/click interactions provide meaningful information 3) Any sound-related animations accurately represent acoustic principles. Deduct 5 points for jarring or scientifically inaccurate animations, 3 points for interactions without educational purpose, and 5 points for missed opportunities to demonstrate how sound affects the ear. The full score is 10 points.
